title: Manhattan: Park Row - Church Street

folder: Park Row & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Park Row, Manhattan, is the street vertically
bisecting this photograph.
The New York Times building was at nos. 37-44 Park Row, with no. 44 (facing the viewer) as the
main entrance.
The Post Office Building (right) fronted on Mail
Street, opposite City Hall Park.
This photograph was taken between 1875 (when the newly constructed Post 0ffice was first occupied) and 1888 (when the New York Times building was
razed).
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Church Street

folder: Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
22 Barclay Street, at the S.W. corner of Church Street, showing St. Peters Roman Catholic Church. Note the 6th Avenue "El" line on Church Street. This was removed in 1939 after widening of the thoroughfare.

About 1914

Winthrop N. Norton, photo

Neg #3875

folder: Park Row & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) City Hall Park: A view of the City Hall in the northward direction from Park Row (foreground). A reception of the members of the Evening Graphic (newspaper, non-existent today, 1937) Modified Marathon from the Bronx to City Hall is in progress. The foundation of this structure is on the old site of the Almshouse; Major E. Livingston laying the first stone on September 20, 1803. It was occupied on August 12, 1811 and completed in 1812.
May 23, 1925

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, exclusive of Civic"Virtue."
October 1925
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)  A southward view, showing the rear of the City Hall with the Woolworth Building overtowering the same. Centre Street appears in the foreground with the pedestrian over-pass to the Brooklyn Bridge on the left. Partially seen on the right is the City Court Building.
January 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4) A more detailed view of the entrance to the City Hall. This view is westward.
October 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
16-10 Barclay Street, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Church Street. No. 16 is St. Peter's Parish House, (Roman Catholic).

June 11, 1927.

P.L. Sperr.

folder: Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, 22 Barclay Street, at the S.E. corner of Church Street. This is the oldest Catholic Church in the city. The original church was built of brick in 1786 and torn down in 1836, in which year the present church was built.

June 11, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: ??Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Barclay Street, west from but not including Church, to and including West Streets. The view shows the site for the new United States Post Office being cleared.

(2)
The same, at a later date, showing clearance still in progress. In the background is shown the New York Telephone Building on West Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, showing the structural frame of the new Post Office.

August 21, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Church Street, north from Barclay Street (foreground, street level not shown), showing the Sixth Avenue "El" lines, it's Park Place station, the westward bend at Murray Street, and the street widening-Eighth Avenue subway construction. The later necessitated a 50 foot slice off of the westerly side of this thoroughfare, extending to Canal Street. At that point (center of view 2 and to the left of view 1) appears the New York Telephone Building in two forms, before and after reconstruction.

View 1: June 4, 1929
View 2: March 27, 1935

P. L. Sperr

folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Church Street, north from Barclay Street (foreground, street level not shown), showing the Sixth Avenue "El" lines, it's Park Place station, the westward bend at Murray Street, and the street widening-Eighth Avenue subway construction. The later necessitated a 50 foot slice off of the westerly side of this thoroughfare, extending to Canal Street. At that point (center of view 2 and to the left of view 1) appears the New York Telephone Building in two forms, before and after reconstruction.

View 1: June 4, 1929
View 2: March 27, 1935

folder: Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
An aerial view of Barclay Street, north side, from and including Church Street to and including West Broadway. The south side of the street has been completely demolished. The view also shows West Broadway, east side, three blocks north to Warren Street.

April 3, 1934.

P.L. Sperr.

(2)
An aerial view of 73-43 Barclay Street, north side, from but not including, West Broadway to but not including Church Street, also showing Church Street, east side, from but not including Barclay Street north to Park Row.

P.L. Sperr.

(3)
An aerial view of 57-33 Barclay Street, north side, from east of West Broadway to east of Church Street, also showing the east side of Church Street from Barclay Street north to Park Place.

April 3, 1934.

P.L. Sperr

folder: Church Street & Park Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
An aerial view of Church Street, at Barclay Street. The view shows Barclay Street, north side, east from and including Church Street, to, but not including Broadway, with the Woolworth Building in the background, and St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in the foreground on Barclay at the
S.E. corner of Church Street.
April 3, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same and showing a further view northward on the east side of
Church Street, to and including Park Place.
March 5, 1934.
. Sperr.  NO REPRODUCTIONS.

folder: Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Barclay Street, north side, west from Church st, to and including West Broadway, and showing in the foreground a portion of the new Post Office site.

March 17, 1935

folder: Barclay Street & Church Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Barclay Street, west from but not including Church, to and including West Streets. The view shows the structural frame for the new Post Office.

August 21, 1935
P.L. Sperr, photographer

folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Church Street, east side, south from Barclay Street, (left), showing St. Peters Roman Chatholic Church (1.v.), the Underwood Building and the old "El' tracks. The latter, at this date, are under denolition. To the right appears the open space caused by
St. Pauls Cemetery.
March 4, 1939
C;ift of W. A . Lucas

folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Church Street, north from Barclay Street, showing the Sixth Avenue "El" photographed against buildings on the east side of this thoroughfare and its Park Place station prior to demolition. View No. 3, being one month later, shows the razing of this structure underway. Note that this thoroughfare has been widened, a slice having been taken off of the west side of same. This occurred during subway construction recently. The property at the left, consisting of 2 square blocks, are holdings of Columbia University. At the northern edge of this, the "El" turns westward thru Murray Street.
January 17, 1939
Views 1 and 2
View 3: February 18, 1939
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS(1 and 2)
Gift of W. A. Lucas

folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
text:

folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Church Street, east side, north from Barclay Street. At the right is a portion of St. Peters Roman Catholic Church. Note the width of thi thoroughfare and the absence of the old "El" structure. The first is attributable to the Eighth Avenue subway constructuon in 1V3o, and the latter to the efforts of Mayor LaGuardia
towards transportation unification.
July 17, 1939
L. Sperr

folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Church Street, west side, north from Barclay Street. En the center is Park Place, Uevoid of its "El" station. The tracks, pillars, etc will shortly follow. Note the additional width on the far side of this thoroughfare. The result of late subway
construction. being thereby apparent.
March 4, 1939
Gift of W . A. Lucas
